title: headingnorth
author: headingnorth
created_time: January 06, 2025, 09:43:44 PMLast edit: January 07, 2025, 06:29:48 PM by headingnorth
content: Nobel laureate Milton Friedman was ahead of his time! If this wasn't the biggest endorsement ever for bitcoin I don't know what is. Milton Friedman's Vision And Bitcoin: A Free Market Economist's Take (FORBES)QuoteThe internet is going to be one of the major forces for reducing the role of government. The one thing that's missing, but that will soon be developed, is a reliable e-cash: a method whereby on the internet you can transfer funds from A to B, without A knowing B or B knowing A... - Milton Friedman, interview 1999

comments.author: odolvlobo

comments.body: Quote from: headingnorth on January 06, 2025, 09:43:44 PMNobel laureate economist Milton Friedman was ahead of his time! If this wasn't the biggest endorsement ever for bitcoin I don't know what is. Not really. There had already been many attempts to create electronic money by 1999, so he was only predicting success of a technology that people were already working on.David Chaum described anonymous electronic money in a paper in 1983 and started DigiCash in 1989.There were more many attempts over the years, but none were successful until Satoshi Nakamoto adapted Adam Back's HashCash idea as an economic solution to the double-spend problem in 2008.But to be fair, Milton Friedman was one of the few economists to recognize the importance and impact of the technology at the time.BTW, your links are broken. Here are working links:https://youtu.be/leqjwiQidlk?t=198https://www.forbes.com/sites/digital-assets/2024/02/18/milton-friedmans-vision-and-bitcoin-a-free-market-economists-take/

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: While I find Milton Friedman undoubtedly insightful and intellectually unique in his own way, I believe the school of thought that truly "predicted" bitcoin belongs to the Austrians. Friedrich Hayek's vision of money[1] that upholds property rights aligns more closely with bitcoin than Friedman's description, even though Friedman connected the rise of individual sovereignty by the advent of the Internet.[1]  Friedrich Hayek predicting cryptocurrency

comments.body: I presume it was meant to happen at one point in the future.  These are ideals.  A system where nobody has control over what another person holds was ideal.  So some people started working on turning that to reality and then the Bitcoin success happened.  But only after many other known attempts and most likely MANY other private attempts at creating such a system.Have you ever watched a very old Science Fiction movie?  Write down all the things they were showing in that movie that did not exist at the time and then make a check list of how many of them turned to reality so far.  People hoped there was a way to communicate from a distance faster, radio and cell phones happened.  Things like that.-----Quote from: Lucius on January 08, 2025, 04:06:10 PMIf we assume that he was right about Bitcoin, who would agree that what he wrote about the internet in the context of the role of government is correct? The internet is a classic double-edged sword, because although on the one hand it has enabled incredible opportunities to spread knowledge and communicate in all possible ways, on the other hand it has enabled surveillance over people that has never existed in human history.It is true, the world was much more Private back in the days when the Internet was inexistent.  Now when everybody has Internet, there is a new found way to spy and surveil but there are also very positive outcomes too.  Back then, how would you send an exceptionally secret message to somebody else with out having anybody know?  Now there is Encryption and messages can reach the recipient in seconds fully encrypted and secured.  How would you move Money from A to B back then with out having any thing on you physically?  Today you can learn a set of words or take a piece of paper into your Wallet and move as much Money as you will.It is better and worse at the same time.  I would be one to agree that the Internet reduced the role of Governments significantly.  That happened on multiple levels in most countries of the world.

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: I won't call it an endorsement. Friedman was just reading the signs of the times and made a bold prediction. He proved to be accurate. But he wasn't endorsing; he was just being realistic of what the internet would bring in the future. He foresaw that such internet money would somehow help criminals do their thing easily. It would also make tax collection harder. But one thing I easily remember about Milton Friedman is his association with Monetarism, a school of thought in economics which believes that governments controlling the supply of money will make them achieve economic stability. That's basically courting danger. That's basically putting too much power in the hands of a few policymakers who are corruptible.

comments.author: BlackHatCoiner
comments.body: Quote from: Synchronice on January 09, 2025, 01:09:33 PMWhat did he exactly mean when he said The internet is going to be one of the major forces for reducing the role of government? I think, he meant that the government won't have as much influence during the era of internet and in that case, he is true. In the world of internet, influencers have more power than the actual government.This is not what he meant. Right now, you're writing on a forum, and likely getting paid in a manner that evades the scrutiny of your government. This is because you're using a currency not controlled by your government, and the person paying you is probably outside your government's jurisdiction. Governments have power when they can physically intervene in the transaction between one person and another (e.g., when you have a job with physical presence, inside your country).  The Internet is an unstoppable force that empowers individual sovereignty by enabling you to operate in a much larger market, that is governed by rules beyond the reach of your government's oversight.
